channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Israel Hamas War Protests Worldwide; Visiting a Donkey Festival in Colombia
item.description: As protests over the Israel Hamas war roil college campuses across the U.S., similar protests are happening elsewhere in the world. We hear from some of them. And a quirky festival in Colombia celebrates the donkey.
item.content:encoded: As protests over the Israel Hamas war roil college campuses across the U.S., similar protests are happening elsewhere in the world. We hear from some of them. And a quirky festival in Colombia celebrates the donkey.
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Scientists welcome new rules on marijuana, but research will still face obstacles
item.description: When marijuana becomes a Schedule III instead of a Schedule I substance under federal rules, researchers will face fewer barriers to studying it. But there will still be some roadblocks for science.
item.content:encoded:
When marijuana becomes a Schedule III instead of a Schedule I substance under federal rules, researchers will face fewer barriers to studying it. But there will still be some roadblocks for science.

(Image credit: Brad Horrigan/Hartford Courant)
item.dc:creator: Rhitu Chatterjee

item.title: Orangutan in the wild applied medicinal plant to heal its own injury, biologists say
item.description: It is "the first known case of active wound treatment in a wild animal with a medical plant," biologist Isabelle Laumer told NPR. She says the orangutan, called Rakus, is now thriving.
item.content:encoded:
It is "the first known case of active wound treatment in a wild animal with a medical plant," biologist Isabelle Laumer told NPR. She says the orangutan, called Rakus, is now thriving.

(Image credit: Armas)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Katie Ledecky tells NPR about her plans for the Paris Olympics — and L.A. in 2028
item.description: Katie Ledecky is used to getting medals, having earned 10 at the Olympics. But on Friday she received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest award a civilian can get from the U.S. government.
item.content:encoded:
Katie Ledecky is used to getting medals, having earned 10 at the Olympics. But on Friday she received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest award a civilian can get from the U.S. government.

(Image credit: Gregory Shamus)
item.dc:creator: Juana Summers

item.title: Campus protests over the war in Gaza have gone international
item.description: Students in the U.K., France and Mexico have sought to erect what many of them call "solidarity encampments," prompting a variety of responses from university authorities and local law enforcement.
item.content:encoded:
Students in the U.K., France and Mexico have sought to erect what many of them call "solidarity encampments," prompting a variety of responses from university authorities and local law enforcement.

(Image credit: Mark Kerrison)
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Have you seen this emotional support gator? Wally's owner says he's lost in Georgia
item.description: Wally has many fans in Pennsylvania and across social media. His owner is enlisting their help, saying Wally was kidnapped, located by a trapper and released into a swamp while vacationing in Georgia.
item.content:encoded:
Wally has many fans in Pennsylvania and across social media. His owner is enlisting their help, saying Wally was kidnapped, located by a trapper and released into a swamp while vacationing in Georgia.

(Image credit: Heather Khalifa)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Siblings can share the darndest quirks — like picking up coins & keys with their toes
item.description: Siblings — especially twins — sometimes share the strangest traits, like throwing a ball with their head or picking up keys and crayons with their toes. Researchers want to know what's up with that.
item.content:encoded: Siblings — especially twins — sometimes share the strangest traits, like throwing a ball with their head or picking up keys and crayons with their toes. Researchers want to know what's up with that.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: How do you help patients who show up in the ER 100 times a year?
item.description: For decades, nonprofits, health insurers and hospitals have been trying to solve the problem of the people who need the emergency room again and again. Here are some of the lessons they've learned.
item.content:encoded:
For decades, nonprofits, health insurers and hospitals have been trying to solve the problem of the people who need the emergency room again and again. Here are some of the lessons they've learned.

(Image credit: Douglas Sacha)
item.dc:creator: Leslie Walker

item.title: Google antitrust lawsuit closes; Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years at Morning Edition
item.description: Google's landmark antitrust lawsuit wraps today. Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years as Morning Edition host. After a week of silence, Biden addresses the pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses.
item.content:encoded:
Google's landmark antitrust lawsuit wraps today. Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years as Morning Edition host. After a week of silence, Biden addresses the pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: Apple shows its steepest quarterly decline in iPhone sales since pandemic's outset
item.description: The 10% drop in year-over-year iPhone sales for the January-March period is latest sign of weakness in a product that generates most of Apple's revenue.
item.content:encoded:
The 10% drop in year-over-year iPhone sales for the January-March period is latest sign of weakness in a product that generates most of Apple's revenue.

(Image credit: Mark Lennihan)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
